message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of prominent stiffness in the legs and painful muscle spasms suggest stiff-person syndrome. Stiff-person syndrome has been associated with Amphiphysin antibodies. The fact that the patient has lung cancer adds to the possibility of paraneoplastic syndrome. Anti-Hu has been associated with paraneoplastic sensory neuropathy and encephalomyelitis. Anti-Ri has been associated with paraneoplastic cerebellar degeneration. Voltage-gated calcium channel antibody has been associated with Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and EMG findings suggest Stiff-person syndrome (SPS). Among the options, only Amphiphysin antibody is associated with SPS. Anti-Hu antibody is associated with paraneoplastic encephalomyelitis/sensory neuropathy, Anti-Ri antibody is associated with paraneoplastic opsoclonus/myoclonus, and Voltage-gated calcium channel antibody is associated with Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome. The patient’s medical history of lung cancer also suggests a paraneoplastic cause of the symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest stiff person syndrome and the needle EMG studies suggest continuous muscle activity. Among the options, only anti-amphiphysin antibodies are associated with stiff person syndrome. Anti-Hu antibodies are associated with sensory neuropathy and encephalomyelitis, anti-Ri antibodies are associated with opsoclonus-myoclonus-ataxia syndrome, and voltage-gated calcium channel antibodies are associated with Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms of muscle stiffness and spasms suggest a myelopathy, and the presence of a paraneoplastic antibody suggests an underlying autoimmune disorder. Among the options listed, amphiphysin antibody has been associated with a paraneoplastic syndrome characterized by stiff-person syndrome and encephalomyelitis. The other options are associated with different neurological disorders. Anti-Hu antibody is associated with paraneoplastic sensory neuropathy, anti-Ri antibody with opsoclonus-myoclonus, and voltage-gated calcium channel antibody with Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest Stiff-person syndrome, which is often associated with paraneoplastic syndromes in patients with lung cancer. Among the options, only Amphiphysin antibody is associated with Stiff-person syndrome. Anti-Hu antibody is associated with paraneoplastic encephalomyelitis/sensory neuronopathy. Anti-Ri antibody is associated with opsoclonus-myoclonus syndrome. Voltage-gated calcium channel antibody is associated with Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and EMG findings suggest Isaacs' syndrome, which is a type of peripheral nerve hyperexcitability syndrome (PNH) that can be caused by paraneoplastic antibodies. Of the options given, amphiphysin antibody is most commonly associated with PNH and Isaacs' syndrome. Anti-Hu is associated with paraneoplastic encephalomyelitis and anti-Ri is associated with opsoclonus-myoclonus syndrome. Voltage-gated calcium channel antibody can be associated with Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome, which presents differently from the patient's symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including increased muscle tone, spastic gait, and muscle spasms, suggest a diagnosis of stiff person syndrome (SPS). Among the options, only Amphiphysin antibody is associated with SPS. Anti-Hu is associated with paraneoplastic encephalomyelitis/sensory neuropathy, anti-Ri is associated with opsoclonus-myoclonus-ataxia syndrome, and voltage-gated calcium channel antibodies are associated with Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome. The history of lung cancer is also suggestive of a paraneoplastic cause of the symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of stiff-person syndrome (SPS) and a history of lung cancer, pointing to the possibility of paraneoplastic SPS. Among the options, only Amphiphysin antibodies are commonly associated with paraneoplastic SPS. Anti-Hu antibodies are commonly associated with paraneoplastic sensory neuropathy and autonomic neuropathy. Anti-Ri antibodies are associated with opsoclonus-myoclonus-ataxia syndrome. Voltage-gated calcium channel antibodies are associated with Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest the diagnosis of paraneoplastic stiff person syndrome, which is commonly associated with anti-amphiphysin antibodies. The other options are associated with different types of paraneoplastic syndromes.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and EMG findings suggest stiff-person syndrome (SPS), which is associated with paraneoplastic antibodies. Among the options, amphiphysin is the most likely to be associated with SPS. Anti-Hu is associated with paraneoplastic sensory neuropathies and encephalomyelitis. Anti-Ri is associated with opsoclonus-myoclonus-ataxia syndrome. Voltage-gated calcium channel is associated with Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome.
